content.description: A cool arete climb with a couple of magical pockets and good edges. The rock right around the first bolt is a little soft but I cleaned the junk. The black stuff is pretty great. Interesting climbing on crimps and edges. Eventually a cool undercling jug out on the right face makes it pretty chill. Named after one of the resident peregrines of the canyon.

Was hoping for a warmup but in typical middle elden fashion there is an awkward bouldery crux passing the bulge at mid-height. Otherwise moderate on mostly great holds, and a couple of mysteriously attached jugs. Also lots of lichen but, "will clean up with more traffic."
content.protection: 10 bolts to keep you from hitting various things. Would be easy to z clip. Loweroffs.
content.location: This route is on the taller walls directly behind the pillar. To access go around the left side of the pillar past donut lust and scramble up some boulders. Climbs the big slab to the right of a chockstone filled chimney.

content.description:
This one has a crumbling foundation. A strange dihedral encounter leads to great, exposed arete climbing up high.

 Could be 11+/12-.
Strange groove climbing up to the donut, then break left in a horizontal to access the easy fun top section.
content.location: Left side of the pillar, the hole features are visible on this route from the bottom of the canyon.

content.description:
Definitely not the best rock to gain the crack but then fun, remarkably skin-friendly hand jams and jugs to the top. We didn't clean this at all and it's pretty good. Jose is a javelina that walked by.

 To descend, walk off the back or rap off the chains on Pilar.
content.location: The crack to the right of Pilar.

content.description: A free-standing pillar, easily visible from the bottom of the canyon. Only about half as tall as the surrounding walls, thus the name. Good rock on this thing because of some water streaks.
